questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with recurrent bleeding. Diagnostic imaging reveals that the bleeding is from the posterior nasal cavity. Which artery, derived from the maxillary artery, is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sphenopalatine artery Explanation: The sphenopalatine artery, a terminal branch of the maxillary artery, is commonly involved in posterior nasal bleeding. It supplies the posterior part of the nasal cavity, including the posterior nasal septum and lateral walls. Total Blood Supply to the Nasal Cavity: External Carotid Artery System: Sphenopalatine Artery( AKA artery of Epistaxis ) : A terminal branch of the maxillary artery supplying the nasal septum and lateral nasal wall. Greater Palatine Artery : A branch of the maxillary artery contributes to the supply of the hard palate and lower part of the nasal septum. Superior Labial Artery : A branch of the facial artery supplies the anterior nasal septum, particularly Little’s area. Internal Carotid Artery System: Anterior Ethmoidal Artery : A branch of the ophthalmic artery that supplies the anterior and superior nasal cavity. Posterior Ethmoidal Artery is also a branch of the ophthalmic artery; it supplies the upper posterior portion of the nasal cavity.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with frequent episodes of anterior epistaxis, which are mild and self-limiting. Examination reveals the bleeding site to be in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Which vascular network is most likely involved in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Kiesselbach’s plexus Explanation: Kiesselbach’s plexus, also known as Little's area , is a highly vascularised region in the anteroinferior portion of the nasal septum , where multiple arteries converge. It is the most common site of anterior epistaxis , especially in children and young adults. Vessels involved in forming the plexus: Artery Branch of Sphenopalatine artery Maxillary artery Anterior ethmoidal artery Ophthalmic artery (from internal carotid artery) Greater palatine artery Maxillary artery Superior labial artery Facial artery (from external carotid artery) Note: The posterior ethmoidal artery is not part of this plexus Clinical Significance: Anterior epistaxis occurs most often in children and young adults, usually due to trauma (nose-picking), dry air, infections, or irritants. Epistaxis in this area is typically mild and self-limiting and can be controlled with local pressure or simple cauterization. Woodruff’s plexus (Option B) is a venous plexus located on the posterior lateral wall of the nasal cavity, particularly in the inferior nasal meatus. It is often involved in cases of posterior epistaxis. Its primary arterial contributors are the sphenopalatine artery, ascending pharyngeal artery, and posterior nasal branches of the sphenopalatine artery. Pterygoid plexus (Option C) is a venous plexus located in the infratemporal fossa behind the maxilla. It is primarily involved in draining blood from the face and orbit. Cavernous sinus (Option D) is a large venous sinus located at the base of the skull on either side of the pituitary gland. It is not involved in epistaxis but drains blood from the brain and orbits.

questions.question: A 28-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of mild anterior epistaxis, mainly from the nasal septum. Upon examination, the source of the bleeding is traced to a venous structure near the anterior septum. Which of the following veins is most likely responsible for the bleeding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Retrocolumellar vein Explanation: The Retrocolumellar vein is located in the anterior septum of the nasal cavity, specifically in the region just behind the columella. It is part of the venous drainage system of the anterior nasal septum, an area prone to anterior epistaxis in young people. Veinous drainage of Nasal cavity The greater palatine vein (Option A) and sphenopalatine vein (Option B) are associated with posterior parts of the nasal cavity and palate and are less likely to be involved in anterior epistaxis. The superior ophthalmic vein (Option D) is located in the orbit and drains structures of the eye, not typically involved in nasal bleeding.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with hypertension presents with profuse nasal bleeding from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, unresponsive to pinching and anterior packing. Nasal endoscopy shows bleeding behind the middle turbinate. What is the likely source of bleeding and appropriate management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sphenopalatine artery, Endoscopic intervention Explanation: The sphenopalatine artery is the most common source of posterior epistaxis in hypertensive patients. It supplies the lateral nasal wall and posterior nasal cavity. Endoscopic ligation or cauterization of the sphenopalatine artery is the preferred treatment for severe, uncontrolled posterior nasal bleeding. Classification of Epistaxis: Feature Anterior Epistaxis Posterior Epistaxis Definition Bleeding from the front of the nose Bleeding that flows backwards into the throat Source of bleeding Kiesselbach's plexus (Anterior ethmoidal artery, Septal branch of Superior labial artery, Septal branch of Sphenopalatine artery, Greater palatine artery) Sphenopalatine artery (Most common) Posterior ethmoidal artery Site Little's area (anteroinferior nasal septum) Posterior or superior parts of the nasal cavity (e.g.Woodruff's plexus) Age Group Mostly in children and young adults More common in adults over 40 years old Usual Cause Trauma (e.g., nose picking, injury) Spontaneous, often associated with hypertension and arteriosclerosis Management Local pressure and conservative measures Postnasal pack, more aggressive treatment often required Reference: PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat, 8th Edition, Page 494,207,208

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of mild epistaxis. On examination, the bleeding site is found in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. What could be the most common cause of epistaxis in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nasal trauma Explanation: In children and young adults, the most common cause of epistaxis is nasal trauma , such as nose-picking or minor injuries. The most common site for this is Kiesselbach's plexus (Little’s area), located in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Causes and Common Sites of Epistaxis in Different Age Groups Age Group Most Common Cause Most Common Site Children/Young Adults Nasal trauma (nose-picking) Kiesselbach's plexus (anterior nasal septum) Older Adults Hypertension Woodruff’s plexus (posterior nasal cavity) All Ages Infections or dryness Kiesselbach's plexus (anterior nasal septum) Hereditary Conditions Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia Multiple sites in the nasal cavity Hypertension (Option A) is a common cause of epistaxis; it is typically seen in older adults, not children. Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (Option C) is a genetic condition that causes recurrent epistaxis due to abnormal blood vessels but is a less common cause in children compared to trauma. Coagulation Disorder (Option D) can lead to epistaxis, but they are not as common as local trauma in children and young adults. Reference: PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat, 8th Edition, Page 205, 206.

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with anterior epistaxis after sustaining a nose injury. Despite initial first aid measures, bleeding continues, and a bleeding point is identified. What is the most appropriate next step if the bleeding persists?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cauterize with silver nitrate Explanation: If a bleeding point is identified in the anterior epistaxis that persists despite initial first aid measures, cauterization with silver nitrate is the most appropriate next step. Embolization and TESPAL (Temporal Endoscopic Surgery for Posterior Anterior Ligament) are reserved for more severe or posterior bleeding. Management of Epistaxis: First Line: (Direct therapy) First Aid: Hippocrates method : Pinch the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes to control bleeding, especially from Little’s area. Trotter’s Method : Have the patient sit forward over a basin to spit blood and breathe through the mouth. Apply cold compresses to induce vasoconstriction. Cauterization: Indication : Effective for anterior epistaxis when the bleeding point is identified . Apply topical anaesthesia and cauterize with silver nitrate or electrocautery. Second Line: (Indirect therapy) Anterior Nasal Packing: Clear the nasal cavity of blood clots, localise the bleeding site, and pack with ribbon gauze soaked in liquid paraffin. The packing may need to stay for 24-72 hours with systemic antibiotics to prevent infection. Posterior Nasal Packing: Use a cone-shaped gauze pack and a rubber catheter or nasal balloon. The pack is guided into the nasopharynx, with an anterior nasal pack to stabilize. Patients need to be hospitalised & balloons with separate bulbs for the postnasal space and nasal cavity are used. Third Line: (Surgical Interventions ) Ligation of Vessels : Maxillary Artery : Ligation via Caldwell-Luc operation for uncontrollable posterior epistaxis. Ethmoidal Arteries : for bleeding from above the middle turbinate. External Carotid : Ligate above the superior thyroid artery for persistent bleeding from the external carotid system. Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL) : Locate and ligate the Sphenopalatine artery (Artery of Epistaxis) to control refractory posterior bleeding. (Option D) Fourth Line (Embolization ) (Option C) Performed by an interventional radiologist through femoral artery catheterisation using absorbable gel foam or coils. It may require bilateral embolisation for unilateral bleeding. Note: The order of ligation is 1. sphenopalatine 2. maxillary 3. ethmoid/ECA Anterior nasal packing (Option A) is a first-line treatment for persistent anterior epistaxis. However, if a specific bleeding point is identified and persists, cauterisation is more effective than packing. Reference: Scott Brown ENT, 8th Edition Page - 1180 Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page - 208,210

questions.question: Which of the following incisions is most appropriate when ligating the anterior ethmoidal artery to control anterior epistaxis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lynch-Howarth incision Explanation: The Lynch-Howarth incision is the most appropriate for accessing the medial wall of the orbit to ligate the anterior ethmoidal artery. The incision is made along the medial canthus of the eye, extending along the inner corner of the eyelid. It allows direct access to this area where the artery can be effectively controlled. Advantages: Direct Access & Minimally invasive. Fig: Lynch-Howarth incision Sublabial Incision (Option B) is typically used to access the maxillary sinus and palatal areas, but it is unsuitable for reaching the anterior ethmoidal artery. Weber-Ferguson Incision (Option D) is a broader incision used for extensive access to the nasal cavity and maxilla, but not specifically for the anterior ethmoidal artery. Gullwing Incision (Option C) is not commonly used in ENT procedures and is primarily used for cosmetic or reconstructive procedures involving the eyelids or facial skin.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia presents with recurrent epistaxis despite conservative measures. Which of the following treatments is considered the last resort for severe, persistent bleeding that has not responded?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Young's Operation Explanation: Young's operation involves the permanent surgical closure of the nostrils and is considered a last-resort treatment for severe, persistent bleeding in patients with Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT) when other methods have failed. Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT) : (Osler-Weber-Rendu disease) An autosomal dominant condition characterised by abnormal blood vessels in the skin, mucous membranes, and internal organs. Clinical Features : Common symptoms include telangiectasia, arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), and aneurysms. Recurrent epistaxis (nosebleeds) occurs in 93% of cases. Management: Initial Treatments : Nasal packing (Option B) , cautery, antifibrinolytics, systemic or topical estrogens. Advanced Treatments : Coagulative lasers ( Nd , Argon, KTP532) (Option C) , septal dermoplasty (Option A) , ligation, and embolization. Last Resort : Young's operation, involving permanent surgical closure of the nostrils, is used for severe, persistent bleeding. Despite the significant disability it may cause, it often improves quality of life by reducing bleeding. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page - 210 Scott Brown ENT, 8th Edition Page - 1180

questions.question: Match the following types of fractures with respective findings. Type of Fracture Finding 1. Jarjavay Fracture a) 2. Class III Nasal Fracture b) 3. Chevallet Fracture c)

A 30-year-old patient presents with a nasal fracture from a frontal blow during a sports accident. The nasal bridge is deviated with swelling and bruising. The patient reports nasal obstruction, but no other facial fractures are noted. What is the most appropriate management approach?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Closed reduction after edema subsides Explanation: Closed reduction after oedema subsides is the preferred approach as it is both effective and less invasive than open reduction. Edema can interfere with accurate closed reduction (Option A ruled out) . It is best to wait until swelling subsides, typically 5-7 days, before performing closed reduction. Management of Nasal Fractures: Diagnosis Physical Examination is the best method for diagnosing nasal fractures. Look for signs such as swelling, periorbital ecchymosis, tenderness, nasal deformity, crepitus, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction. X-rays : These may not always reveal fractures. Necessary views include Waters’ view, lateral views, and occlusal view. Treatment Simple Fractures : Generally, no treatment is required if there's no displacement. Monitor for natural healing. Closed Reduction : Timing : Ideally performed before significant edema develops or after it subsides (Option C) (usually 5-7 days). Technique : Use a straight blunt elevator guided by digital manipulation from outside for depressed fractures. Reduce laterally displaced nasal bridge with firm digital pressure in the opposite direction. Disimpaction of impacted fragments requires Walsham or Asch’s forceps. Septal fractures and hematomas should be managed with Asch’s forceps. Packing : Unstable fractures require intranasal packing and external splintage. Open Reduction (Option B): Rarely required early & Considered if closed methods fail, for certain septal injuries & if a patient presents late. Correction of Deformities : May need rhinoplasty or septorhinoplasty for healed deformities from trauma. Nasal packing and observation (Option D) may help manage bleeding or minor fractures but does not address the alignment of the fractured bones. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page - 213

questions.question: During a closed reduction procedure for a nasal septum, the surgeon selected a forceps, as depicted in the image, and asked the intern to identify it. What is the name of these forceps?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Asch’s forceps Explanation: The instrument shown in the above image is Asch’s forceps , an angulated forceps that is used in the closed reduction of the nasal septum. Tilley’s forceps (Option A), also known as Tilley’s dressing forceps, have a box joint. They are used for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removing foreign bodies from the nose. Walsham’s forceps (Option B) are straight and covered by rubber tubing. They are used to disimpact and reduce nasal bone fractures. Hartmann’s forceps (Option C) have a screw joint, and the jaw is serrated and grooved. It is used the same as Tilley’s forceps, i.e., for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removing foreign bodies from the nose.

questions.question: A 32-year-old female involved in a car accident presents to the emergency department with a hanging palate and hanging teeth after her face collided with the dashboard. All of the following are true regarding this type of fracture, except:

options.B: Referred to as a transverse maxillary fracture
options.D: Fracture line traverses the nasal and maxillary sinus floors

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) High risk of CSF rhinorrhea Explanation: The clinical scenario is indicative of a Le Fort type I or Guerin’s fracture, characterised by the hallmark signs of a hanging palate and hanging teeth, with the absence of CSF rhinorrhea. Features of Le Fort I Fracture: A type of maxillary fracture, also known as Guerin’s fracture or Transverse maxillary fracture . (Option B) The fracture line is horizontal and runs above and parallel to the palate, crossing the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates. (Option D) Fig: Le Fort I Fracture It is characterised by hanging palate and hanging teeth. CSF rhinorrhea is absent. Guerin’s sign is observed, which is characterised by bluish discolouration of the palate due to rupture of the Greater palatine artery. (Option A) Fig: Guerin’s sign

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with severe facial pain, swelling, and trouble closing his mouth after a high-impact fall. Examination shows a hanging maxilla. What type of fracture does this indicate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Le Fort type II fracture Explanation: The clinical scenario is indicative of a Le Fort type II or pyramidal fracture , a type of maxillary fracture with the hallmark sign of a hanging maxilla. Classification of Fractures of the maxilla: Le Fort I (Option A) Le Fort II (Option B) Le Fort III (Option C) Also known as Guerin’s fracture or Transverse fracture Pyramidal fracture Craniofacial disjunction Fracture line Runs above and parallel to the palate, crossing the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates. Passes through the nasal root, lacrimal bone, orbital floor, upper maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates Note: can cause infraorbital nerve injury. Traverses the root of the nose, ethmoid-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures, and the upper pterygoid plates. Characteristic feature Hanging palate and hanging teeth Hanging maxilla Complete detachment of the facial bones from the cranial bones CSF Rhinorrhea Absent May be present High risk of CSF Rhinorrhea Management of maxillary fractures: After diagnosing the fracture through clinical examination and x-ray, fixation of maxillary fractures can be achieved by: Interdental wiring Intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring as in zygomatic fractures. Wire slings from the frontal bone, zygoma or infraorbital rim to the teeth or arch bars. Tripod fracture (Option D) , also known as a zygomatic fracture , involves three fracture lines: zygomaticofrontal , zygomaticotemporal , and zygomaticomaxillary . The characteristic features include depression of the zygomatic arch , localised pain aggravated by talking and chewing, and trismus (restricted jaw movement). It may cause infraorbital nerve injury.

questions.question: A 26-year-old male presents with jaw pain, swelling, difficulty opening his mouth, and trouble chewing after being struck in the face during a fight. What is the most common site for mandibular fractures?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Condylar region Explanation: The most common site of mandibular fracture is the condylar region. Fracture of Mandible Fractures of the mandible have been classified according to the Dingman classification , as per their location as shown in the figure below, Fig: Dingman classification The sequence of mandibular fracture sites, from most common to least common, is as follows: Condylar region (weakest part of the mandible) (Option A) Angle of mandible (Option B) Body of mandible (Option D) Symphysis menti. (Option C) Clinical features: Pain and trismus (most common) Malocclusion of teeth and deviation of the jaw to the opposite side on opening the mouth (in case of displaced fragments) Guardsman fracture (Parade ground fracture) A variant of mandibular fracture in which trauma on the symphysis menti results in the bilateral sub-condylar region fracture. Fig: Guardsman fracture Managed by Open reduction with titanium wiring . Complication: TMJ (temporomandibular joint) ankylosis can occur due to prolonged immobilisation from closed reduction performed for more than three weeks for fractures.

questions.question: A 22-year-old woman reports experiencing pain, swelling, blurred vision, and double vision following a facial injury from a basketball. Based on the clinical presentation and radiograph findings, which extraocular muscle is most likely restricted, leading to impaired eye movement?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Inferior rectus Explanation: The given scenario is a blowout fracture showing a teardrop sign in a CT scan . Blowout Fracture (fracture of floor of orbit): Cause A large blunt object striking the eye globe. Location The floor of the orbit. Clinical features Ecchymosis of the lid, conjunctiva and sclera. Enophthalmos with inferior displacement of the eyeball. Diplopia (displacement of the eyeball or entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles). Hypoaesthesia or anaesthesia of the cheek and upper lip (infraorbital nerve involvement). Presence of periorbital emphysema and oedema. Restricted eye movement (entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle) Forced duction test To determine if the inferior rectus muscle is impinged at the fracture site. A small forceps is used to release the muscle from the fracture site. Improvement in eye movement suggests muscle impingement. Diagnosis X-ray and CT scan shows the characteristic “teardrop” sign due to herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus. Management Reduction (Indicated if associated with zygomatic/maxillary fractures or significant functional impairment) Surgery is required for persistent diplopia, enophthalmos, or muscle entrapment. It typically involves reconstructing the orbital floor to correct anatomical displacement and relieve
